The numerous pensions and benefits under the Social Security Act 1991 are automatically paid through ongoing appropriation authority enabled by that act , in what is called a special appropriation .

This means that almost 80 % of spending receives automatic approval on an ongoing basis - and that a government can not change the way this money is spent without also changing the underlying acts involved .

Under section 53 of the constitution the Senate is not allowed to introduce any money - related legislation of its own , and is prohibited from amending laws on taxation or the ordinary annual services of government .

This is why we have two appropriation bills :  Bill 1 is for ordinary annual services , which include departments ' expenses , many grant programs and the like ;  Bill 2 is for other types of payments , including new equity for government agencies and a variety of payments to states and territories .
The Senate is obliged by the constitution to pass Appropriation Bill No. 1 .

Contrary to popular belief , in the constitutional crisis of 1975 the Senate did not reject Appropriation Bill ( No. 1 ) - it delayed , sat on its hands and did not pass it .
